text: This is the special word which Habakkuk the man of God saw.
speaker: Narrator

text: O Lord, how long must I call for help before You will hear? I cry out to You, “We are being hurt!” But You do not save us.
speaker: Narrator

text: Why do you make me see sins and wrong-doing? People are being destroyed in anger in front of me. There is arguing and fighting.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Law is not followed. What is right is never done. For the sinful are all around those who are right and good, so what is right looks like sin.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Look among the nations, and see! Be surprised and full of wonder! For I am doing something in your days that you would not believe if you were told.
speaker: Narrator

text: I am bringing the Babylonians to power. They are people filled with anger who go across the whole earth to take homes that are not theirs.
speaker: Narrator

text: They fill others with fear. They make their own law about what is fair and honored.
speaker: Narrator

text: Their horses are faster than leopards, and show less pity than wolves in the evening. Their horsemen come on running horses from far away. They fly like an eagle coming down to get food.
speaker: Narrator

text: They all come in anger. Their armies move like the desert wind. They gather prisoners like sand.
speaker: Narrator

text: They make fun of kings and laugh at rulers. They laugh at every strong city and build a battle-wall to take it.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then they move through like the wind and keep going. They are guilty men, whose strength is their god.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Have You not lived forever, O Lord, my God, my Holy One? We will not die. O Lord, You have chosen them to judge. You, O Rock, have chosen them to punish us.
speaker: Narrator

text: Your eyes are too pure to look at sin. You cannot look on wrong. Why then do You look with favor on those who do wrong? Why are You quiet when the sinful destroy those who are more right and good than they?
speaker: Narrator

text: Why have You made men like the fish of the sea, like things which move along the ground that have no ruler?
speaker: Narrator

text: The Babylonians bring all of them up with a hook, and pull them away with their net. They gather them together in their fishing net, and so they have joy and are glad.
speaker: Narrator

text: So they give gifts in worship to their net. They burn special perfume to their fishing net, because their net catches all the good things and good food they need.
speaker: Narrator

text: Will they empty their net forever and keep on destroying nations without pity?
speaker: Narrator

text: I will take my stand and keep watch. I will take my place on the tower. And I will keep watch to see what the Lord will say, and how I should answer when He speaks strong words to me.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord answered me and said, “Write down the special dream on stone so that one may read it in a hurry.
speaker: Narrator

text: For it is not yet time for it to come true. The time is coming in a hurry, and it will come true. If you think it is slow in coming, wait for it. For it will happen for sure, and it will not wait.
speaker: Narrator

text: As for the proud one, his soul is not right in him. But the one who is right and good will live by his faith.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Also, wine fools the proud man, so he does not stay at home. He is like the grave who always wants more. Like death, he never has enough. He gathers all nations for himself, and gathers all people for his own.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Will not all these people make fun of him and say, ‘It is bad for him who gathers what is not his and makes himself rich with other people’s money. How long will this go on?’
speaker: Narrator

text: Will not those to whom you owe money rise up all at once? Will they not wake up and make you afraid? Then they will take what belongs to you.
speaker: Narrator

text: Because you have robbed many nations, the rest of them will rob you. For you have killed men. You have destroyed lands and cities and everyone in them.
speaker: Narrator

text: “It is bad for him who builds his house by sinful ways, to put his nest in a high place to be safe from trouble!
speaker: Narrator

text: You have brought shame upon your house by destroying many nations. You are sinning against yourself.
speaker: Narrator

text: The stone will cry out from the wall, and the roof will answer it from the wood.
speaker: Narrator

text: “It is bad for him who builds a city with blood, and builds a town with wrong-doing!
speaker: Narrator

text: Is it not the will of the All-powerful Lord that people work for what will burn up and nations make themselves tired for nothing?
speaker: Narrator

text: For the earth will be filled with knowing of the Lord’s shining-greatness, as the waters cover the sea.
speaker: Narrator

text: “It is bad for him who makes his neighbors drink, mixing in his poison to make them drunk, so he can look on their shame!
speaker: Narrator

text: You will be filled with shame instead of honor. Now you yourself drink and let your own shame be seen. The cup in the Lord’s right hand will come around to you, and your greatness will turn to shame.
speaker: Narrator

text: The bad things you have done to Lebanon will come back to you. Because you have killed its animals, now they will make you afraid. This will happen because of all the killing you have done. You have destroyed lands and cities and everyone in them.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Of what worth is a false god when a workman has made it? Of what worth is an object of worship, a teacher of lies? For the workman trusts in his own work when he makes these false gods that cannot speak.
speaker: Narrator

text: It is bad for him who says to a piece of wood, ‘Wake up!’ or to a stone that cannot speak, ‘Get up!’ Can this teach you? See, it is covered with gold and silver. There is no breath in it.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the Lord is in His holy house. Let all the earth be quiet before Him.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Shigionoth tells of this prayer of Habakkuk, the man of God.
speaker: Narrator

text: O Lord, I have heard of what You have done, and I am filled with fear. O Lord, do again in our times the great things which You have done before. Remember to show loving-kindness, even when You are angry.
speaker: Narrator

text: God comes from Teman. The Holy One comes from Mount Paran. His shining-greatness covers the heavens, and the earth is full of His praise.
speaker: Narrator

text: He is as bright as the sun. He has light shining from His hand, where His power is hidden.
speaker: Narrator

text: Disease goes before Him, and much trouble comes after Him.
speaker: Narrator

text: He stood and looked over the earth. He looked and shook the nations. The lasting mountains were broken to pieces, and the old hills fell down. His ways last forever.
speaker: Narrator

text: I saw the tents of Cushan in trouble. The tent curtains of the land of Midian were shaking.
speaker: Narrator

text: Were You angry with the rivers, O Lord? Was Your anger against the rivers? Or were You angry with the sea? You rode on Your horses. You rode on Your war-wagons saving people.
speaker: Narrator

text: You took the covering off Your bow and put the arrows to the string. You divided the earth with rivers.
speaker: Narrator

text: The mountains saw You and shook. The flood of waters flowed by. The sea made its noise and its waves rose high.
speaker: Narrator

text: The sun and moon stood still in the heavens at the light of Your arrows, at the shining of Your spear.
speaker: Narrator

text: You walked over the earth in Your anger. In anger You crushed the nations under foot.
speaker: Narrator

text: You went to save Your people, to save Your chosen ones. You crushed the leader of the land of the sinful and laid him open from thighs to neck.
speaker: Narrator

text: With his own spear You cut through the head of his soldiers. They came like a storm to send us everywhere, finding joy as if they were destroying in secret those who had it very hard.
speaker: Narrator

text: You stepped on the sea with Your horses, on the waves of many waters.
speaker: Narrator

text: I heard and my body shook. My lips shook at the sound. My bones began to waste away and my legs shook. Yet I will be quiet and wait for the day of trouble to come upon the people who fight against us.
speaker: Narrator

text: Even if the fig tree does not grow figs and there is no fruit on the vines, even if the olives do not grow and the fields give no food, even if there are no sheep within the fence and no cattle in the cattle-building,
speaker: Narrator

text: yet I will have joy in the Lord. I will be glad in the God Who saves me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The Lord God is my strength. He has made my feet like the feet of a deer, and He makes me walk on high places.
This is for the song leader, on my different kinds of harps.
speaker: Narrator
